From Pastry to Pandemics: The Epic Story of Pfizer, a Journey by Two Immigrants that Revolutionized Global Medicine

A German refugee from a family of pharmacists arrives in the United States, aiming to alleviate stomach discomfort by creating a series of tonics that would later evolve into a multimillion-dollar business. The young man behind this venture is Carl Christian Friedricher, the founder of the pharmaceutical company Pfizer, now a giant in the medical industry. Join me once again to explore the story of a young entrepreneur with little money in his pocket but an immense hunger for success.

It all begins in the year 1848, as the remnants of the Holy Roman Germanic Empire, under the care of the German Confederation, are crumbling due to a revolution led by unified classes of republicans, bourgeoisie, and workers seeking to change the course of Germany. In the midst of these upheavals, a 24-year-old from a liberal family named Carly Facer, the son of a pastry chef, had to flee to the United States with his cousin. Embarking on an adventure to America with two other cousins, they carried savings and loans from family totaling around $2000 in their pockets.
